string.text: A 12-gauge cartridge loaded with 5mm buckshot (40 rounds). It has tremendous stopping power and lethality at close distances. Intended for use only in smoothbore firearms.

A 12-gauge cartridge with a solid slug. Typically used for hunting large animals, but suitable for other purposes as well: its heavy 39-gram bullet does not penetrate but effectively crushes body armor.
Dart bullet. The fins stabilize the bullet, increasing combat accuracy. The massive steel body of the bullet can penetrate any body armor.
Standard 20-gauge cartridge loaded with 6mm buckshot. It has tremendous stopping power and lethality at close distances. Intended for use only in smoothbore firearms.

In 1951, the 9mm Makarov pistol and its cartridge, 9x18mm, were adopted by the Soviet Army. The bullet with a steel core in a lead jacket saves lead and increases the ability to penetrate non-metallic barriers, but cannot penetrate a steel-plated vest.

Armor-piercing cartridge with the same impulse and dimensions as the "native" 9x18 PM cartridge. Developed by the Tula CBP. At a distance of 11 meters, it penetrates a vest with a 2.4mm steel plate and a Kevlar liner with a 100% probability, and at a distance of 30 meters, it penetrates a 1.25mm titanium plate and 30 layers of Kevlar fabric.

The 9 mm Parabellum cartridge (more commonly known on the North American continent by the surname of its creator, Georg Luger - "9 mm Luger") is the only cartridge that has earned the right to be called simply "9 mm" for its more than a century of existence. The good ballistic qualities of the 9x19mm cartridge made it the standard ammunition for pistols and submachine guns in most countries of the world.

One of the enhanced modifications of the 9 mm Parabellum cartridge - 9x19 +P+, meaning the pressure in the barrel channel is very high - this type of cartridge is used in the police force, less often in "civilian" pistols. Effective against armored targets.

5.7x28 mm SS190 - a pistol cartridge created in 1986 to replace the 9x19 mm Parabellum. Compared to the 9x19 mm cartridge, it provides greater shot accuracy, less recoil, greater effective firing range, armor penetration, and is characterized by reduced ricochet. This cartridge occupies a niche between pistol and intermediate (rifle) cartridges. The 5.7x28 mm cartridge is used in the FN P90 Personal defense weapon and the FN Five-seveN pistol.
5.7x28 SS195 JHP - a cartridge with an expanding bullet, it has less penetrating power than the SS190, but greater stopping power and lethality.

.50 Action Express (also .50 AE, 12.7 x 33, 12.7x32.6 mm) - a cartridge developed in 1988 for the Israeli Desert Eagle pistol. One of the most powerful unitary pistol cartridges in the world. It has a blunt-nosed bullet, which ensures the enormous stopping power of this cartridge.
Magnum (Latin Magnum, from magnus - large, great) - a high-powered cartridge compared to a standard cartridge of the same caliber. Also a weapon designed for this type of cartridge.

.45ACP (Automatic Colt Pistol) caliber cartridge with a jacketed bullet has remained popular for over a century. The heavy bullet with a relatively weak powder charge has not very high velocity but has significant stopping power. Used against personnel and light unarmored vehicles.

.45ACP (Automatic Colt Pistol) caliber cartridge with Hydra-Shok bullet from Federal is known for its high stopping power, being the standard ammunition in this caliber for many years. Hydra-Shok remains a good choice today.

Standard army cartridge caliber 5.45x39 mm (index 7N10). Due to the reduced recoil impulse and increased initial bullet velocity, the cartridge provides higher combat accuracy than its predecessor, the 7.62x39 mm.
Army cartridge caliber 5.45x39 mm with an armor-piercing bullet (index 7N22). Inside the bullet is a solid alloy armor-piercing core. Effective against body armor.

The cartridge with a heavy bullet designated SS109 was developed in the 1980s in Belgium at Fabrique Nationale (initially it was developed for the FN FNC assault rifle and the FN Minimi light machine gun). By the mid-1980s, this cartridge was adopted as the standard for all NATO countries.
NATO cartridge caliber 5.56x45 mm with enhanced armor-piercing bullet. Known under the index P112. Effective against body armor. Widely used in the small arms of NATO armies and special forces.

Special sniper cartridge. It has a subsonic flight speed, which allows it to be used in silent weapons for special operations. Thanks to its caliber, it has high stopping power, and due to the heavy bullet of special design, it penetrates most body armor at distances up to 200 meters.

A cheaper modification of a special armor-piercing cartridge. It has a subsonic flight speed, which allows it to be used in silent weapons for special operations. The bullet design uses a thermally hardened steel core, allowing it to penetrate most body armor at distances up to 200 meters. Due to the too high pressure of the powder gases, it is not recommended for use in the AS "Val" assault rifle and the VSS "Vintorez" sniper rifle.

Special cartridge with an armor-piercing bullet. It has a subsonic flight speed, which allows it to be used in silent weapons for special operations. Thanks to its caliber, it has high stopping power, and due to the special bullet design - a partially open core made of hardened steel, it penetrates most body armor at distances up to 400 meters.
Soviet pistol cartridge caliber 7.62mm. Simple full metal jacket bullet with a lead core.
Soviet pistol cartridge caliber 7.62mm. Bullet with a steel core, improved armor penetration.
Soviet assault rifle cartridge caliber 7.62mm (index 57-N-231). Simple full metal jacket bullet with a steel core.
Soviet armor-piercing assault rifle cartridge caliber 7.62mm (index 7N23). Bullet with a thermally hardened steel core, improved armor penetration.
NATO standard rifle cartridge. Caliber - 7.62mm. Simple full metal jacket bullet with a lead core.
NATO standard armor-piercing rifle cartridge. Caliber - 7.62mm. Bullet with a steel core, improved armor penetration.
Standard army sniper cartridge 7.62x54 mm PS (index 7H1). The cartridge bullet has a blunt-ended steel core. A cost-effective modification of a sniper cartridge for sniper rifles.

Specially designed sniper armor-piercing cartridge 7.62x54 mm SNB (index 7H14). In terms of accuracy, it is equivalent to the sniper cartridge 7H1, but significantly surpasses it in armor-piercing action due to the introduction of a sharpened hardened steel core into the bullet design.

Cartridge with armor-piercing bullet 7.62x54 mm BP (index 7N26). The bullet has a core made of hardened tool steel. Designed to defeat live targets behind light armored covers at distances up to 500 m.
The 8x57 IS cartridge was the main cartridge of the German army during the First World War and the Second World War.

The cartridge with the heavy pointed bullet s.S (schweres Spitzgeschoss) weighing 12.8 grams received the widest distribution in the German army. It was intended for firing from machine guns, hand-held machine guns, rifles, and carbines that were in service with the Wehrmacht.
Created as a special sniper cartridge for long-range shooting, but is widely used today by hunters and sports shooters as well.

12.7x55 mm SC-130 - a Russian rifle cartridge with a subsonic bullet speed, created at the TSNIITOCHMASH for silent and flameless defeat of protected targets and live targets in heavy body armor at ranges up to 600 meters.

12.7x99 mm (known as ".50 BMG", "12.7x99 mm NATO") - a large-caliber cartridge of NATO armies. It was created in the 1920s as ammunition for the Browning M1921 heavy machine gun. After the Second World War, the cartridge was standardized in NATO and is produced by various NATO member countries according to unified technical specifications.

A cassette consisting of damaging and energy elements for the Gauss pulse electromagnetic rifle. 2mm capsules are used as damaging elements. The energy source is a encapsulated fragment of the "Flash" artifact.
A cassette for the Gauss pulse electromagnetic rifle with reduced capacity. Reduced capacity is due to makeshift manufacturing conditions of the elements.
Cartridge with high-penetration bullet. The bullet has an armor-piercing core made of hardened tool steel. Designed to defeat live targets behind light armored covers at distances up to 500 m.

Fragmentation-high-explosive anti-personnel grenade "Pencil" ("Fragment"). Allows to hit covered enemy at a distance exceeding the throwing range of a hand grenade. Equally effective against live targets and lightly armored vehicles.
Hand defensive grenade, its fragments are able to penetrate medium protection vests within a 20 m radius.
Offensive hand grenade with a small blast radius. The blast wave radius is about 5 m.
Hand smoke grenade. Designed to create a smoke screen. Formation time - 10 seconds.
Chemical illuminating grenade. Designed to illuminate areas of terrain during night combat, as well as to blind and disorient the enemy. Action time is less than a minute.

40mm VOG-25 shot (7P17) is a unitary projectile and is made according to the "caseless" scheme, i.e. the throwing charge along with the ignition means is located in the bottom part of the grenade body.

40mm VOG-25P or "Podkidish" (7P24) shot - a fragmentation grenade for grenade launchers, the main and main difference of which is the head detonator, providing the grenade "bounce" after hitting the ground and its explosion in the air, which increases its damaging effect.
Type of 40mm rounds for NATO caliber grenade launchers. Developed to hit targets in cover.
Optical sight for the Israeli IMI Galil assault rifle.
Permanent and variable magnification optical sights are installed on hunting rifles and are designed for aiming it during shooting. Sights are mounted on weapons using special mounts.

The 1P78 scope is designed for equipping rifles and machine guns. The scope has a magnification of 2.8X, the optical scheme is similar to the 1P77 scope. Developed by TsKIB "Tochpribor" (Novosibirsk), chief designer - S.I. Mikhalenko.

Designed for observation and aimed fire during the dark hours with starlight and moonlight. Installed on all types of small arms with a side mounting rail - AK74, AK74M, AK101, AK102, AK105, AK107, AK108, AN94, sniper rifles AS, VSS.

The night scope 1PN93-4 for the SVD sniper rifle is designed for battlefield observation and aimed shooting in conditions of natural night illumination at ambient temperatures from plus 50°C to minus 50°C and relative humidity up to 100% (at 25°C).

The Saracen scope is one of the latest developments of the Novosibirsk Instrument-Making Plant, serially produced since 2011. Its distinguishing feature is its light weight (670 g) and compact dimensions. At the same time, the scope body is made of metal. The scope is equipped with a 2+ or 3 generation night vision device.

The Cobra scope provides confident aiming in natural light conditions (bright sunny day, deep twilight, and moonlit night) thanks to the presence of 16 levels of manual brightness adjustment of the aiming mark. The alignment of the aiming mark and the target in the same plane allows aiming with one or two eyes, providing the shooter with an unrestricted field of view, and conducting effective rapid fire at rapidly moving, small-sized, and suddenly appearing targets for a short time.

The original design of OKP scopes allows for aimed fire from unstable positions and in rapidly changing conditions, reduces fatigue, and, if necessary, allows the use of standard mechanical devices. The main feature of the scope is the mounting of the reflex sight without a mechanical frame that obscures a significant part of the shooting sectors. Protection of the reflex sight in extreme conditions is provided by a thin and durable metal visor that practically does not interfere with shooting.
EO Tech is a global leader and exclusive manufacturer of holographic sighting systems for small arms.

The open-type collimator sight "C-More Railway" can be instantly mounted on a "Weaver" or "Picatinny" mount. Therefore, such a sight can be used with almost any weapon - shotgun, rifle, revolver, crossbow, paintball and airsoft gun. The sight body is made of aluminum.

DOCTER collimator sights are excellent optical sighting devices of modern design. Due to their small size and mass, as well as compact tubular construction, these sights offer rich application possibilities for both hunting and sports. Reliable performance, high optical power, attractive design, and reliable operation even in extreme weather conditions make the DOCTER Sight scope indispensable.

The PK-A collimator sight is a modern lightweight, sealed, easy-to-learn sight for hunting carbines "Tigr" with a side rail for mounting optical sights. The sight is designed for precise aiming of AK74N, RPK74N, AKMN-1, RPKN-1 weapons in various lighting conditions - during the day, at dusk, in poor visibility, and rapidly changing lighting conditions. The sight is sealed and filled with dry nitrogen to prevent fogging of internal optical surfaces.
A 4x optical sight for NATO rifles.
A compact sight for small arms, developed and manufactured by the Swedish company Aimpoint M68 AB.
An optical sight with variable magnification designed to replace the 4x ACOG sight from Trijicon.

The ELECTRO SIGHT 1x22x33 collimator sight for quick aiming. Impact resistant, suitable for all types of weapons with a Picatinny rail. The choice of brightness level of the aiming mark illumination (7 levels) allows the sight to be used in various lighting conditions.
Closed collimator sight Barska RED DOT 2x30mm. Multilayer optics coating, 100% waterproof, fog-proof. Suitable for all types of weapons with a Picatinny rail.
Widely used optical sight of Soviet production. Mounting on the weapon is done using the "dovetail" type mount.
PSO-1M2 - for aimed shooting from the Dragunov SVD sniper rifle caliber 7.62. The sighting scales are designed for shooting from 100 m to 1300 m.

PSO-1M2-01 - a sight for aimed shooting from a special (grooved) sniper rifle VSS caliber 9 mm and a special AS machine gun caliber 9 mm. The sighting scales are designed for shooting from 100 m to 400 meters (step 50 meters). For shooting in twilight, the sights have illumination of the grid. Instead of the 2RC63 battery, a standard AA battery is currently used as a power source.
PU (from Shortened Sight) - a Soviet optical sight, originally created in 1940.
A sight produced in 1939 for the Mauser 98k rifle.
Optical sight of fixed magnification (2.7 diopters). Optimized for combat at medium distances, as well as for use in urban conditions. Mounting on the weapon is done using the "dovetail" type mount.
The passive action electronic-optical device 1PN58 (NSPUM-2) is designed for observation and providing aimed shooting at night. It is mounted on the weapon using a "dovetail" type mount.
The scope has variable magnification and target acquisition and illumination device. Designed for use by special purpose groups. It is mounted on the weapon using a "dovetail" type mount.
Optical sight SUSAT L9A1 - Sight Unit, Small Arms, Trilux. Mostly used for aimed firing from light firearms at medium and long distances. It is installed on the Picatinny rail.
Optical sight ACOG, Trilux. Mostly used for aimed firing from light firearms at short and medium distances. It is installed on the Picatinny rail.
Optical sight ACOG-D - Trilux, Dusk. Designed for close combat in low light conditions. It is installed on the Picatinny rail.
Optical sight ACOG-N - Trilux, Night. Equipped with an integrated night vision device. Designed for combat in the absence of light sources. It is installed on the Picatinny rail.
Optical sight ACOG-RF - Trilux, RangeFinder. Allows for independent adjustment of magnification for increased firing accuracy. It is installed on the Picatinny rail.
Device for silent and flameless shooting for 9mm pistols and submachine guns.
Silent shooting device for PB pistol (6P9).
Silent shooting device for SR-3M "Vikhr" and VSK-94 rifles.
Silent shooting device for FN Five-Seven pistol.
Silent shooting device for APS and OC-33 "Pernach" pistols.
Silent shooting device for .45 caliber pistols and submachine guns.

Tactical rifle suppressor (hereinafter referred to as ATG suppressor) designed to reduce sound and flame when firing from 5.56mm Kalashnikov AK101 and AK102 rifles, as well as 7.62mm Kalashnikov AK103 and AK104 rifles.

Tactical silencer "TGP-A-5.45" for 5.45mm AK series rifles and RPK-74 machine guns. The silencer design does not include a rubber obturator, and there is no need to use subsonic bullets. However, the accuracy of shooting slightly deteriorates when installed.

Tactical silencer for SVD ("TGP-V"). Can be installed on the SVD over the standard slotted cylindrical flame arrester. Designed to provide shooter position concealment (day and night), reduce gunshot sound intensity, and virtually eliminate flash. Reduces the sound impact on the shooter (avoids deafening in enclosed spaces).
The sound moderator from Hexagon company is designed for carbines and rifles of 12 caliber.
PBS-1. Device for silent and flameless shooting from 7.62mm Kalashnikov assault rifle. When the silencer is installed, firing is done with subsonic bullets.
PBS-4. Device for silent and flameless shooting from 5.45mm Kalashnikov short assault rifle (AKS-74U).
AAC M4-2000 model suppressor is designed for installation on most rifles and carbines of 5.56x45 mm caliber.
AAC 762-SDN-6 suppressor is designed for use with 7.62x51 NATO caliber ammunition.
Silencer for some sniper rifles, including Remington 700, M24, Barrett M98B, SV-98.

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] VOG-25, VOG-25P Shot
 
Single-shot, muzzle-loaded grenade launcher "Campfire" for rifles used in Warsaw Pact countries. Self-cocking trigger mechanism, with manual safety and automatic shot blocking in case of incorrect installation.

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] VOG-25, VOG-25P Shot
 
Under-barrel grenade launcher GP-34 was developed based on the army grenade launcher GP-30 "Shoe" in the early 2000s at the design bureau of "Izhmash". The new grenade launcher (by the way, the first and only one developed at Izhmash) was designed as a competitor to the Tula GP-30M "Shoe" and is intended for installation on full-size Kalashnikov rifles: AK-74M, modern "hundred series", AN-94 "Abakan", AEK-971, as well as on the newest AK-12. In service with the Armed Forces and the Ministry of Internal Affairs of the Russian Federation, supplied for export.

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] M397A1 Shot
 
Underbarrel single-shot grenade launcher with mounting for installation on Picatinny rail.

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] M397A1 Shot
 
The underbarrel grenade launcher M320 was created to replace the underbarrel grenade launcher M203. The Picatinny arsenal held a competition for a new 40mm underbarrel grenade launcher. The competition was won by Heckler & Koch company in early 2006. The M320 was produced based on Heckler & Koch AG36, but they are not fully identical. Production started in November 2008. The grenade launcher was officially presented in July 2009 at Fort Bragg, North Carolina, by the 1st Brigade of the 82nd Airborne Division of the USA.

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] M397A1 Shot
 
Underbarrel grenade launcher developed by the German arms conglomerate Heckler & Koch to replace HK 79. The main platform for it is the HK G36 rifle.

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] M397A1 Shot
 
The FN40GL is a modification of the FN GL1 grenade launcher, adapted for use in FN SCAR assault rifles. Structurally, the FN40GL grenade launcher is a single-shot, rifled weapon, made according to the traditional scheme with a movable barrel.

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Sights Cobra EKP-8-02, Cobra EKP-1S-03, 1P29 "Tulip", PSO-1M2-01
 

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Silencer 9x39mm
 
The 9A-91 automatics are based on diverting gunpowder gases from the barrel channel. Locking is done by turning the bolt, with 4 combat stops. The fire control system is cock-type, allowing for single and continuous fire.

Croatian submachine gun created in the early period of the civil war in Yugoslavia. Used by self-defense units, partisan-rebel and sabotage-terrorist formations, as well as some units of the Croatian army, but was not officially adopted. The submachine gun became popular among criminals because the wartime-produced weapons were not traced to the MIA ballistics database and (except for individual exhibition samples) did not even have markings.

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Silencer for APS
 
9mm Stechkin automatic pistol - automatic pistol developed in the late 1940s - early 1950s by designer I.Ya. Stechkin and adopted by the Armed Forces of the USSR in 1951, simultaneously with the Makarov pistol. APS is designed for arming officers directly participating in combat operations, as well as for soldiers and sergeants of some special units.

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Sights Cobra EKP-8-02, Cobra EKP-1S-03, 1P78 "Chestnut", 1PN93-1, OKP-7
 

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Underbarrel grenade launcher GP-25
 
Modern rifle designed to replace the aging AK-74. One of the main features is the ability to fire in bursts of 2 rounds with high accuracy (at a distance of one hundred meters, both bullets hit the same point). This significantly increases the chances of hitting the target due to the combined stopping and penetrating action of the bullets.

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Sights ACOG, Barska ES AC10632, EOTech
 

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Silencer AAC M4-2000
 
Galil ACE is an Israeli family of automatic weapons, further development of the Galil rifle (in turn, a "descendant" of the Kalashnikov rifle).

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Sights ACOG, Aimpoint M68, Barska ES AC10632, EOTech, 1PN23 "Saracen"
 

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Silencer AAC 762 SDN-6
 
Galil ACE is an Israeli family of automatic weapons, further development of the Galil rifle (in turn, a "descendant" of the Kalashnikov rifle).

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Silencer 9mm
 
AEK-919K "Chestnut" - Russian submachine gun, developed in the mid-1990s by employees of the Kovrov Mechanical Plant Design Bureau (chief designer - Pavel Sedov, scientific supervisor - Mikhail Tarasov, with the support of the head of the KB Stanislav Koksharov). The Austrian Steyr MPi-69 submachine gun was taken as a sample, but after the release of the experimental batch of AEK-919, defects were discovered, after which changes were made to the basic design. The updated sample was indexed AEK-919K.

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Sights Cobra EKP-8-02, Cobra EKP-1S-03, 1P78 "Chestnut", 1PN93-1, OKP-7
 

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Underbarrel grenade launcher GP-25
 

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Silencer TGP-A
 
The rifle is designed according to the traditional layout scheme (front magazine position) and structurally largely repeats the Kalashnikov rifle - a rotating bolt and a gas-operated reloading mechanism are used. The rifle is designed for 5.45x39 mm cartridges, there are also versions of this rifle for 5.56 mm NATO (AEK-972) and 7.62x39 mm (AEK-973) cartridges.

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Sights Cobra EKP-8-02, Cobra EKP-1S-03, 1P78 "Chestnut", 1PN93-1, OKP-7
 

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Underbarrel grenade launcher GP-25
 

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Silencer TGP-A
 
The rifle is designed according to the traditional layout scheme (front magazine position) and structurally largely repeats the Kalashnikov rifle - a rotating bolt and a gas-operated reloading mechanism are used. The rifle is designed for 7.62x39 mm cartridges, there are also versions of this rifle for 5.45x39 mm (AEK-971) and 5.56 mm NATO (AEK-972) cartridges.

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Sights ACOG, Aimpoint M68, Barska ES AC10632, EOTech, 1PN23 "Saracen"
 

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Underbarrel grenade launcher GP-34
 

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Silencer TGP-A
 
AK-12 is a fundamentally new rifle, implemented using the general scheme and technical solutions of previous Kalashnikov rifles. This sample is equipped with a tactical grip and a 45-round magazine.

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Sights ACOG, Aimpoint M68, Barska ES AC10632, EOTech, 1PN23 "Saracen"
 

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Silencer TGP-A
 
AK-12 is a fundamentally new rifle, implemented using the general scheme and technical solutions of previous Kalashnikov rifles. This sample is equipped with a tactical grip and a 45-round magazine.

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Installation of sights is not possible due to the absence of "dovetail" mounting
 

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Underbarrel grenade launcher GP-25
 

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Silencer PBS-1
 
7.62mm Kalashnikov rifle (AK) - rifle adopted by the USSR in 1949. AK and its modifications are the most common firearms in the world. According to estimates, up to 1/5 of all firearms on Earth belong to this type (including licensed and unlicensed copies, as well as third-party developments based on the AK).

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Installation of sights is not possible due to the absence of "dovetail" mounting
 

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Underbarrel grenade launcher GP-25
 

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Silencer PBS-1
 
AKS (GRAU index - 56-A-212M) - a variant of the AK with a folding metal stock, intended for airborne troops. It was adopted simultaneously with the AK. Initially, it was produced with a stamped receiver, and since 1951 - with a milled receiver due to a high percentage of defects in stamping.

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Sights Cobra EKP-8-02, Cobra EKP-1S-03, 1P78 "Chestnut", 1PN93-1, OKP-7
 

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Underbarrel grenade launcher GP-34
 

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Silencer TGP-A
 
The Kalashnikov rifle chambered in 5.45 mm, developed in 1970 by designer M. T. Kalashnikov and adopted by the armed forces of the USSR in 1974. It is a further development of the AKM. The development of the AK-74 is associated with the transition to the new low-impulse cartridge 5.45x39 mm.

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Installation of sights is not possible due to the absence of "dovetail" mounting
 

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Underbarrel grenade launcher GP-25
 

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Silencer TGP-A
 
The Kalashnikov rifle chambered in 5.45 mm, developed in 1970 by designer M. T. Kalashnikov and adopted by the armed forces of the USSR in 1974. It is a further development of the AKM. The development of the AK-74 is associated with the transition to the new low-impulse cartridge 5.45x39 mm.

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Silencer TGP-A
 
A variant of the Kalashnikov rifle chambered in 5.45 mm, equipped with a tactical handguard, grip, KV-04 rail with OKP-7 sight, and an enlarged 45-round magazine.

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Sights Cobra EKP-8-02, Cobra EKP-1S-03, 1P78 "Chestnut", 1PN93-1, OKP-7
 

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Underbarrel grenade launcher GP-25
 

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Silencer TGP-A
 
AK-74M - Modernized AK-74. Equipped with a side-folding plastic stock and a universal mount (dovetail rail) for mounting sights, both optical and night vision, on the left side of the receiver. Thus, the AK-74M replaced four models at once: AK-74, AKS-74, AK-74N, and AKS-74N.

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Sights Cobra EKP-8-02, Cobra EKP-1S-03, 1P78 "Chestnut", 1PN93-1, OKP-7
 

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Underbarrel grenade launcher GP-25
 

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Silencer TGP-A
 
For sale in the West and in third world countries, two models of the new Kalashnikov rifle AK-101 (standard) and AK-102 (compact) were developed for the most common 5.56 mm NATO low-impulse cartridge SS 109. The most noticeable external difference of these rifles is the shape of the plastic magazine, much straighter than magazines for Soviet 5.45 or 7.62 mm cartridges.

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Sights Cobra EKP-8-02, Cobra EKP-1S-03, 1P78 "Chestnut", 1PN93-1, OKP-7
 

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Silencer ATG
 
For sale in the West and in third world countries, two models of the new Kalashnikov rifle AK-101 (standard) and AK-102 (compact) were developed for the most common 5.56 mm NATO low-impulse cartridge SS 109. The most noticeable external difference of these rifles is the shape of the plastic magazine, much straighter than magazines for Soviet 5.45 or 7.62 mm cartridges.

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Sights Cobra EKP-8-02, Cobra EKP-1S-03, 1P78 "Chestnut", 1PN93-1, OKP-7
 

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Underbarrel grenade launcher GP-25
 

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Silencer TGP-A
 
AK103 - Export version of the AK-74M rifle, which uses the 7.62x39 mm (Soviet cartridge model 1943) accordingly. The AK103 can use magazines from AK/AKM rifles.

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Sights Cobra EKP-8-02, Cobra EKP-1S-03, 1P78 "Chestnut", 1PN93-1, OKP-7
 

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Silencer TGP-A
 
AK104/AK105 are modifications of the AK-103 and AK74M respectively, with a shortened barrel by 101 mm. The intermediate (between AK74M and AKS-74U) barrel length allowed reducing the dimensions of the weapon, leaving the gas chamber in the same position relative to the muzzle cut as in the AK74M, rather than moving it back (as in the AKS-74U). This increased the standardization of the entire "hundredth" family.

The M16 (official designation - Rifle, Caliber 5.56 mm, M16) is an American automatic rifle caliber 5.56 mm, developed based on the AR-15 rifle and adopted in the 1960s. The M16 and its variants remain the primary weapon of the American infantry to this day. This is one of the most common models of small arms in the world - more than 8 million units have been produced.

M16A1 - an improved version of the M16. The main differences: the appearance of the bolt catch mechanism and an improved buffer for the bolt carrier (reducing the rate of fire to 750-850 rounds per minute and eliminating bolt bounce and stoppages), a more reliable flash suppressor with closed slots, chromed bolt carrier (to prevent corrosion), reduction of rifling twist rate from 356 to 305 mm (improved bullet stability but increased dispersion at distances over 400 m), bayonet lug for attaching a bayonet. Also, specifically for the new rifle, a 30-round magazine and a suppressor designed for firing standard (non-subsonic) cartridges were created. It was in service with the US Army from 1967 to 1985.

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Suppressor AAC M4-2000
 
M16A2 - a variant of the M16A1 rifle adapted for the SS109/M855 cartridge. Differences from the M16A1: reinforced barrel, improved sights marked up to 800 m, new handguards and buttstocks made of impact-resistant polyamide, replacement of full auto mode with burst fire mode after 3 shots, new flash suppressor with slots only on the upper part (which compensated for upward muzzle climb). The new rifle was equipped with lightweight plastic 30-round magazines.
M16A3 - a variant of the M16A2 rifle with full auto mode, used by the Navy. The carrying handle and sights are identical to the M16A2. It appeared in 1992 under the designation M16A2E3.

M16A4 - a variant of the M16A2 rifle. Instead of the carrying handle on top of the receiver (which became detachable), a Picatinny rail was installed. Additional Picatinny rails can be installed on the handguard.
A variant of the M16A4 with desert camouflage and a Leupold Mark4 scope.

Ruger SR-556 - an American semi-automatic carbine produced by Sturm, Ruger & Company, Inc. The weapon was introduced in 2009 and became Ruger's first model in the AR-10 family. The next variant in this series was the Ruger SR-762 chambered in .308. It is one of the few AR-15 rifles using a gas piston system. Production ceased in January 2016 after the introduction of the Takedown variant with a lightweight Keymod handguard.
M79 - a single-shot 40mm grenade launcher adopted by the US Army in 1961. Developed between 1951-1961 by the American corporation Springfield Armory. Its unofficial nickname is the "elephant gun."

5.56x45mm light machine gun manufactured by Fabrique Nationale (Belgium), serial production began in the 1980s. The development of this weapon was entrusted to the promising designer Ernest Vervier, the creator of the FN MAG machine gun.

MG 42 (Ger. Maschinengewehr 42) - a German general-purpose machine gun of the Second World War. Developed by the Metall-und Lackwarenfabrik Johannes in 1942. Among Soviet soldiers and allies, it received nicknames such as "bone saw," "Hitler's saw," "MG," "Crusader."
The MAC-10 and MAC-11 submachine guns were developed by Gordon Ingram in 1964. The main idea was to create a compact concealed carry submachine gun that was also lightweight.

PP-2000 - a Russian 9mm submachine gun developed by a team of designers from the Tula KBP (Acad. V.P. Gryazev, specialists B.I. Kuznetsov and A.I. Rasskazov). The PP-2000 is positioned as a weapon for law enforcement units operating in urban conditions, as well as personal defense weapons for certain categories of military personnel.

The 7.62mm submachine gun model 1941 Shpagin system (PPSH-41) - a Soviet submachine gun developed in 1940 by designer G.S. Shpagin for the 7.62x25mm TT cartridge and adopted by the Red Army on December 21, 1940. Along with the PPSh-43, the PPSh-41 was the main submachine gun of the Soviet armed forces in the Great Patriotic War.

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] 9mm Suppressor
 
The submachine gun was developed in 1972 by order of the Ministry of Defense of the USSR (R&D "Bush") by designers from the Central Design Bureau of Sporting and Hunting Weapons in Tula: N.M. Afanasyev, D.P. Pleshkov, and N.V. Trukhachev. The layout scheme of the Czechoslovak submachine gun Scorpion Vz.61 of 1961 was taken as a basis.

The KRISS Vector is a submachine gun developed by Transformational Defense Industries. It uses the semi-free bolt system, directing the bolt group recoiling downward at a large angle. This system is called Kriss Super V.

The pistol was developed in the second half of the 20th century based on the PM pistol to arm reconnaissance groups and special service personnel. This model is considered morally outdated, but in skilled hands, it remains a very effective weapon.

The most common pistol in the Zone, a legacy of the Soviet era, the PM is one of the best representatives of compact self-defense weapons. It is characterized by small size, exceptional reliability, ease of use and maintenance. Among the drawbacks are the short range and shooting accuracy, low bullet effectiveness, and (compared to modern pistols of the same class) quite large mass with insufficient magazine capacity.
An engraved PM that Degtyarev received as an award. The engraving reads: "For the successful completion of particularly dangerous assignments and the courage and bravery displayed during them."

The 9mm Makarov pistol modernized PMM (GRAU Index - 56-A-125M) is a Russian pistol developed in the early 1990s as part of the "Grach" research and development topic. It participated in the competition for a new army pistol under the designation "Grach-3."

The Protecta is a combat shotgun designed to increase the firepower of army and police special units. Its main advantages are large magazine capacity and practical rate of fire; main drawbacks are considerable size and weight of the weapon, as well as low reload speed. It is rarely encountered in the Zone and is mainly used for clearing mutant lairs.

%c[255,1,255,255]%c[default] Sniper Suppressor
 
There are many variations of the rifle for different cartridges. The standard cartridge is 7.62x51mm NATO (.308 Win). Technically, it is a magazine rifle with a longitudinally sliding rotating bolt. Magazine capacity depends on the caliber and can range from 3 to 5. It is a top product of Remington Arms company.

The Remington 870 is an American shotgun first introduced in 1950 by Remington Arms company. Thanks to its distinctive reloading action, it is one of the most famous pump-action shotguns in the world. Produced in various modifications, it is suitable for military and police, as well as for hunters and sportsmen, and also for self-defense.

The revolver-type grenade launcher, in which the chambers of the drum are formed by six rifled barrels. Designed to fight the enemy in cover and fire on areas, it is also useful for attacking well-defended objects or in combat against particularly resilient creatures.

A manual modification of a belt-fed machine gun. Despite its high mass and unsatisfactory battle accuracy, it has found quite wide application in the Zone. It is mainly used to suppress numerically superior enemies and during clearing operations of mutant lairs.

The 7.62mm PKP "Pecheneg" machine gun (GRAU Index - 6P41) is a Russian unified machine gun developed based on the PKM. Designed to defeat enemy manpower, fire and transport assets, and air targets. Developed by TsNIITochMash.

A grenade launcher from the 1960s, remaining in huge quantities in army depots, from where it ended up in the Zone. It is a smoothbore single-shot recoilless launcher. Its considerable size and weight make this weapon not very common among stalkers, but due to its enormous destructive power and ease of use, it has found admirers in the Zone.

The only remaining model in serial production of the popular pistol worldwide. This weapon is characterized by excellent ergonomics and outstanding shooting accuracy. The rifle has a modified flash hider and can be equipped with Picatinny rails for additional accessories.

The FN SCAR (Special Operations Forces Combat Assault Rifle) is a weapon system developed by the American branch of the Belgian company FN Herstal for participation in the competition to create a new rifle for USSOCOM fighters in 2004.

The Franchi SPAS-12 (Special Purpose Automatic Shotgun) is an Italian shotgun developed in the late 1970s. It is a dual-mode shotgun, meaning it can be used as either a semi-automatic or pump-action weapon. Switching between firing modes is done by pressing a button under the barrel and moving the barrel slightly forward or backward until it clicks.
The USAS-12 is an automatic shotgun developed by John Trevor in the late 1980s based on the ideas of another American designer, Maxwell Atchisson, who created the Atchisson Assault Shotgun.

Russian magazine-fed sniper rifle, created from 1998 to 2000 by a team of designers under the leadership of Vladimir Stronsky and serially produced by the Izhevsk Mechanical Plant. The SV-98 is designed to engage appearing, moving, open, and unmasked, unprotected, and individually armored enemy forces at distances of up to 1000 m.

The DVL-10 is a lightweight, compact rifle for new and existing subsonic ammunition, developed for special service and combat missions requiring special accuracy and range. Existing models on the market did not provide the required characteristics, primarily in terms of grouping and shooting range from silent weapons. Thus, the concept of DVL was born.

In the military, it is mainly used to engage distant targets that cannot be hit with an assault rifle, but stalkers appreciate the SVD largely because its bullet can penetrate even the thickest mutant skin or body armor.

The 7.62mm Tokarev self-loading rifle model 1940 (SVT-40), as well as the Tokarev automatic rifle model 1940, are modifications of the Soviet self-loading rifle developed by F. V. Tokarev. The SVT-38 was developed as a replacement for the Simonov automatic rifle and was adopted by the Red Army on February 26, 1939. The first SVT model 1938 was released on July 16, 1939. Mass production began at the Tula plant on October 1, 1939, and from 1940 at the Izhevsk arms factory.

It has a higher rate of fire compared to the original with less mass, while the combat accuracy at short and medium ranges remains approximately the same. Today it enjoys well-deserved popularity among the military and stalkers.

A Chinese automatic rifle created based on the SKS to replace the Type 56 self-loading carbine. Adopted by the PLA in 1968, hence sometimes referred to as Type 68 in Western sources.

Well-known even among novice shooters, the single-barreled rifle MR-18 (IZH-18) has been produced at the Izhevsk Mechanical Plant for over fifty years. It continues to enjoy decent demand. One of the most popular hunting rifles is characterized by relatively low mass, excellent balance, simple, yet effective construction.

A widely spread hunting shotgun thanks to sufficient accuracy and good stopping power, providing more reliable protection against mutants than a pistol. Very cheap and accessible compared to most types of weapons, so it is actively used by beginners and bandits on the outskirts of the Zone.

Unique TOZ-34 "Gont" with Leupold Mark sight for long-distance shooting.

Hunting double-barreled shotgun TOZ-66 was produced from 1967 to 1978, intended for industrial and amateur hunting. Developed based on the TOZ-63 shotgun, it is distinguished by a reinforced barrel box.

Developed based on the MC 20-01 shotgun, it differs from it with a shortened barrel and a folding metal stock. A rubber shock absorber is installed on the stock. Longitudinal-sliding bolt with rotation upon locking on two combat stops located in the front part of the bolt stem. Initially equipped only with magazines from MC-20-01 for two rounds, then - magazines for 4 rounds.
TOZ-194 - a Russian pump-action shotgun, developed in the mid-1990s based on the TOZ-94 shotgun design. Produced at the Tula Arms Plant.
An unstudied specimen, the mechanism of which is not yet established. Nevertheless, the weapon is clearly malfunctioning: pressing the trigger does not lead to any result.

Excellent Western-made pistol, known for its high reliability, large magazine capacity, good combat accuracy, and perhaps the best ergonomics in its class. After entering the Zone, it became one of the most common pistols among both professionals and newcomers with money.

Winchester Model 1873 - a famous model of lever-action rifle manufactured by Winchester Repeating Arms Company in the USA since 1873. It enjoyed immense popularity and is known as the "gun that won the West".
